Born and raised in Hangzhou, I spent eighteen years there before moving to Sydney, Australia. During my years in Hangzhou, I didnâ€™t fully appreciate its beauty, often feeling more drawn to larger cities like Shanghai and Beijing. However, after relocating to Sydney, everything changed. I began to deeply miss Hangzhouâ€”the weeping willows by the lake in spring, the blooming lotus flowers in summer, the vibrant red maple leaves on Beishan Street in autumn and the pervasive scent of osmanthus in the air, the wintersweets and the misty mornings of drizzly winter days. Even my momâ€™s homemade Hangzhou cuisine, though not entirely authentic, became a cherished memory.

Due to COVID restrictions and work and study commitments, I hadnâ€™t been home in six years. When I finally returned, I was struck by a profound sense of alienation. Familiar restaurants and shops near my home had disappeared. The large square where people once gathered to dance, socialize, and sing had been replaced by two sprawling shopping malls. The city itself had transformedâ€”its subway system had expanded from just two lines six years ago to eight lines, now covering almost every corner. Towering high-rises filled the cityscape, one after another, creating a stark contrast to the Hangzhou I once knew.

Yet, amidst all these changes, West Lake remained the same. Walking along its shores, I was once again captivated by its timeless beauty and serenity. Some say Hangzhou is defined by just one lake, but to me, its charm lies in so much moreâ€”the natural landscapes, cultural and historical heritage, poetry, and art. Itâ€™s no wonder Bai Juyi, the renowned Tang dynasty poet, once wrote: â€œWhen I recall the south of the Yangtze River, Hangzhou comes foremost to my mindâ€ (å¿†æ±Ÿå—ï¼Œæœ€å¿†æ˜¯æ­å·).

So here it isâ€”Hangzhou, my beloved city.

### About Hangzhou
**Hangzhou (æ­å·)** is the capital city of the Zhejiang providence. Nestled in the heart of eastern China, Hangzhou is a city where timeless charm meets vibrant modernity. Renowned for its breathtaking **West Lake (è¥¿æ¹–)**, a symbol of natural beauty and serenity, Hangzhou has inspired poets and painters for centuries. Beyond its historic allure, the city thrives as a hub of innovation, home to global tech giant Alibaba and a burgeoning digital economy. With its harmonious blend of ancient temples, bustling markets, cutting-edge architecture, and verdant tea plantations, Hangzhou offers a captivating journey through history and progress.

**Beishan Street (åŒ—å±±è¡—)** is a picturesque historic avenue that runs along the northern shore of the iconic West Lake. Known for its blend of natural beauty and cultural heritage, the street is lined with ancient trees, traditional Chinese architecture, and several historical sites, including former residences of notable figures and old temples. The area exudes a tranquil charm, making it a favorite spot for leisurely strolls, photography, and cultural exploration. Visitors often admire its cobblestone paths, scenic lake views, and the way it seamlessly combines modernity with history. Beishan Street is not just a thoroughfare but a journey into Hangzhou's rich past, offering a serene retreat from the city's bustling pace.

The Broken Bridge is located at the eastern end of Bai Causeway on the West Lake. **The origin of the name "Broken Bridge"**<br>
There are many legends about the origin of the name "Broken Bridge." One famous legend describes that after a winter snow, when viewed from Baoshi Hill to the south, West Lake is draped in silver, with Bai Causeway stretching across snow-covered willows and frosted peach trees. The stone arches of the Broken Bridge are exposed, with no cover or barriers, allowing the ice and snow to melt under the sunlight, while the ends of the bridge remain covered in bright white snow. The faintly visible stone bridge arches seem to appear and disappear, contrasting with the gray-brown bridge deck, creating an illusion of the bridge being broken. Thus, it is named the Broken Bridge. It is selected as one of the Ten Scenes of West Lake, named "**Lingering Snow on Broken Bridge (æ–­æ¡¥æ®‹é›ª)**". <br><br>
**Love Bridge**<br>
The Broken Bridge in Hangzhou holds a special place in Chinese folklore as one of the "Three Love Bridges" and is famously associated with the legend **"The Legend of the White Snake" (ç™½è›‡ä¼ )**. According to the tale, it was on the Broken Bridge that Bai Niangzi (ç™½å¨˜å­), a white snake spirit, and Xu Xian (è®¸ä»™), a mortal man, first crossed paths. This chance meeting blossomed into a legendary romance that remains one of China's most cherished love stories.</span>

#### **Wenlan Pavilion (æ–‡æ¾œé˜): A Treasure of Chinese Culture**
<center>
  <img src="images/wenlange1.png" width="100%">
  <img src="images/wenlange2.png" width="100%">
  <img src="images/wenlange5.png" width="100%">

<span style="font-size: 0.95em;"> 
Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025. <br><br>
**Wenlan Pavilion (æ–‡æ¾œé˜)** is one of the esteemed "Seven Pavilions of the Complete Library in Four Sections" (ä¸ƒé˜è—ä¹¦æ¥¼). Constructed in 1782 during the Qing Dynasty under the decree of Emperor Qianlong, it was designed to house a copy of the monumental literary collection, **Siku Quanshu (å››åº“å…¨ä¹¦, Imperial Collection of Four Divisions)**. This compilation, regarded as the largest collection of Chinese texts in history, encompasses works across the four divisions: classics, history, philosophy, and literature.<br><br>
While other Qing Dynasty libraries were either safeguarded in imperial locations or tragically lost to the flames of war, Wenlan Pavilion and its Imperial Collection of Four Divisions endured. Despite facing the ravages of conflict and the changes of time, it was ultimately restored, thanks to the persistent efforts of generations of literati and scholars who recognized, transcribed, and preserved the scattered volumes. This remarkable survival stands as a cultural miracle in Chinese history.<br><br>
Today, Wenlan Pavilion, situated by the picturesque West Lake, continues to embody profound cultural significance. It serves as a living testament to the enduring legacy of Chinese culture and scholarship, spreading its rich humanistic heritage to the world.
</span>

**Juxian Pavilion (é›†è´¤äº­)** in winter. Photo captured by Weisi on 8 Jan 2025. In the fourth year of the Yongzheng reign of the Qing Dynasty (1726), Li Wei, the Governor of Zhejiang, rebuilt the Archery Pavilion, renaming it **Juxian Pavilion** (Pavilion of Gathering Virtues). He used this location to inspect the military training of the Eight Banners troops. Over time, Tingzi Bay gradually became a regular venue for the Eight Banners soldiers to practice horseback archery and martial arts.
Today, Juxian Pavilion is a popular destination where people gather to enjoy the scenic views and capture stunning photos, especially at sunset. It is at its most beautiful in summer, surrounded by the vibrant blooms of nearby lotus flowers.
</div>

#### **Yongjin Pool (æ¶Œé‡‘æ± )**
<center>    
  <img src="images/hubin6.png" width="100%">
  <img src="images/hubin7.png" width="100%" height="50%">

<div style="font-size: 0.95em; text-align: left;">
**Yongjin Pool (æ¶Œé‡‘æ± )** is a well-known scenic spot, famous for its golden ox and the legend associated with it. According to the tale, in the Han Dynasty, a golden ox lay hidden at the bottom of West Lake. Whenever the lake dried up, causing crops to wither and people to suffer from water shortages, the golden ox would emerge, spouting water to refill the lake, providing irrigation for nearby farmlands and meeting the daily water needs of the local people. In an attempt to please the emperor, local officials once forced the villagers to drain the lake to capture the golden ox as a tribute. When the lake was emptied and the golden ox appeared, the officials rushed into the lake to seize it. However, the golden ox raised its head and roared in anger, spewing water that quickly flooded the area, drowning all the officials. From that time on, the waters of West Lake never dried up again, and the golden ox was never seen. <br><br>
The "Golden Ox Emerging from Water" sculpture in Yongjin Pool was erected in 2002. A waterside pier has also been built on the eastern shore of Yongjin Pool to provide visitors with a spot for taking photos and enjoying the scenery.<br><br>
The first photo is captured by Weisi on 6 Jan 2025. The second photo is sourced from the internet.
</div>
